awd_titl_txt: Laboratory Investigation of Arched Magnetoplasma Eruptions on the Sun
awd_abstract_narration:
The main science goal of this project is to develop a better understanding of physical processes that occur before, during, and after the eruption of arched magnetic field structures on the Sun that are filled with plasma, a hot gas of electrons and ions.  The solar atmosphere is a chaotic stew of such arched magnetoplasma structures that cover broad spatial and temporal scales. The tiny ones are the size of California; the Earth would be barely noticeable inside a big one. The arched magnetoplasma structures efficiently confine plasma until they become unstable and erupt. Some of these eruptions drive extremely intense energetic events that influence systems and technologies in orbit and on Earth. To get insight into the eruption processes, highly reproducible arched magnetoplasma eruptions will be generated and studied in a laboratory experiment at UCLA. In addition, collaborative efforts between plasma and solar physicists will be initiated to enhance the impact of this project in broader areas of physics. This project will also provide educational opportunities to high-school students and train a graduate student towards his/her doctorate.

Contemporary models of solar eruptions attempt to explain initiation and evolution of arched magnetoplasma structures on the Sun. It is difficult to test these models by solely relying on constraints provided by remote observations, especially since key elements (such as magnetic-field and plasma flow in the corona) are not directly measured. In this project, a series of specially designed laboratory plasma experiments will be conducted to simulate the eruption of arched magnetoplasma structures under a variety of scenarios on the Sun. These experiments will provide data with a high spatio-temporal resolution in three dimensions and will have the flexibility of testing a variety of models of solar eruptions, such as dynamic injection of magnetic flux into an arched magnetoplasma and slow-storage of magnetic energy driving a fast eruption. The arched magnetoplasma will evolve in a large background plasma produced by another source. Thousands of identical eruptions will be routinely produced and their evolution will be recorded using movable diagnostic probes and a fast CCD camera. To complement these studies, remote observational results on solar eruptions will be compared with the laboratory results for few selective cases. These research efforts are expected to contribute to a wide range of topics relevant to the Sun such as coronal mass ejections, loss of equilibrium due to force imbalance in an arched flux rope, and excitation of waves and oscillations in the solar atmosphere.

por.por_cntn:
Arched magnetic flux ropes are ubiquitous structures of plasma (ionized gas with sufficiently high density of positive and negative charged particles) in the solar atmosphere that carry electrical current. These structures of plasma can efficiently transport energy and matter from the surface (photosphere) to the outer atmosphere (corona) of the Sun, since their foot-points originate from the sub-photospheric regions and their leading edge extends up to coronal heights of a million miles. Traditional astronomical and spacecraft observations reveal a long persistent appearance of solar plasma ropes lasting from days to weeks, which is followed by their sudden eruption. These violent and spectacular eruptions trigger energetic phenomena such as solar plasma jets and coronal mass ejections. A detailed understanding of the trigger mechanisms is crucial in resolving outstanding puzzles in solar physics, including the impact of flares and coronal mass ejections on the Earth's space weather. This project has supported in building a new plasma device (solar plasma device) at UCLA that can help explore solar physics relevant processes in a controlled laboratory environment with a precise control over conditions.

Under this project, laboratory exploration of eruptive plasma phenomena using an appropriately-scaled model have provided a better insight into physical processes that drive solar eruptions. The novel feature of the experiment is its ability to produce tens of thousands of nearly identical eruptions within a day and capture important plasma parameters in three-dimension using automated probes and modular sensors. The experiment was upgraded to improve the performance and reliability of two different hot-cathode plasma sources that form the arched magnetized plasma and the ambient plasma. A three-dimensional probe drive system was also constructed. Results on the excitation of plasma waves (such as intense EIT waves on the Sun) and global oscillations of the arch following the eruption were presented in scientific meetings. Recent results from this plasma device have highlighted the importance of neutrals in the generation of a three-dimensional current system of spectacular jets of plasma in the lower solar atmosphere. A research paper titled “Evolution of an Arched Magnetized Laboratory Plasma in a Sheared Magnetic Field” was published in the Journal of Plasma Physics and another manuscript titled “Dynamic Formation of a Transient Jet from Arched Magnetized Laboratory Plasma” is nearly ready for publication in a research journal. Research on this project have resulted in ten invited talks and twelve contributory presentations by the project team in scientific meetings. These results have generated significant interest in the solar physics community, and collaborative efforts have been initiated in this cross-disciplinary area of research.

 

The solar plasma device was used in supporting the undergraduate research of two students. In addition, a graduate student researcher is working in the area of laboratory plasma astrophysics on this device and about to complete his Ph.D. The research from this project will directly affect a wide range of topics relevant to the Sun such as coronal mass ejections, onset of flares, loss of equilibrium due to force imbalance, and excitation of waves and oscillations. Overall, this project has improved our understanding of the basic plasma phenomena associated with eruption of arched plasmas.
